title: AI Hub vs. Non-Hub Wage Divergence by 2030
description: Projected wage gap between AI hub cities (SF, Seattle, NYC, Austin) and non-hub metros for tech and knowledge workers by 2030.

overlays.label: Brookings: San Jose 43% AI-exposed vs 31% in Las Vegas
Anthropic: AI usage concentrated by income & geography
IMF: employment 3.6% lower in AI-vulnerable regions
NBER: 6.1M workers lack adaptive capacity; 86% women

sources.title: Future of Work Report: AI at Work
sources.excerpt: 55% of LinkedIn members hold jobs that stand to be impacted by generative AI. By 2030, the skills required for jobs will change by up to 65%.

sources.title: The Lightcast Global AI Skills Outlook
sources.excerpt: AI skills are becoming a universal priority beyond Silicon Valley. The U.S. leads in AI skills demand, with San Francisco commanding the highest average tech salary at $177,636.

sources.title: AI and the Geography of Opportunity
sources.excerpt: AI adoption is concentrating economic gains in a handful of superstar cities, widening the already large metro-level wage divergence.

sources.title: The Spatial Distribution of AI's Labor Market Effects
sources.excerpt: Each AI job in a hub city creates 3-5 local service jobs. Non-hub cities see net job losses. The spatial multiplier amplifies geographic wage divergence.

sources.title: The Geography of AI Jobs — Indeed Hiring Lab
sources.excerpt: AI-related roles offer a 38% wage premium in top-10 tech metros vs. national average. Non-AI roles in same metros show only 12% premium.

sources.title: Conversation starter: are AI jobs booming or overhyped?
sources.excerpt: AI jobs pay more than similar jobs that do not focus on AI, with a typical premium of 25%. The share of AI jobs among new job listings increased 123% from 2023 to 2024.

sources.title: AI is driving mass layoffs in tech, but it's boosting salaries by $18,000 a year everywhere else, study says
sources.excerpt: Job postings for non-tech roles that require AI skills offer 28% higher salaries — an average of nearly $18,000 more per year. The divide between AI-skilled and non-AI-skilled workers is widening.

sources.title: Occupational Employment and Wage Statistics — Metropolitan Areas 2025
sources.excerpt: Computer and mathematical occupations in San Jose-SF-Oakland MSA: $178K median. National median: $108K. Gap up from 48% to 65% since 2022.

sources.title: The State of AI Adoption in U.S. Businesses | 2025 Trends
sources.excerpt: Mountain region leads US AI adoption at 42%, followed by Pacific at 39%. Southeast lags at 22%. Regional adoption gaps correlate with widening wage divergence.

sources.title: The geography of generative AI's workforce impacts will likely differ from those of previous technologies
sources.excerpt: 43% of workers in San Jose could see AI shift half or more of tasks, vs only 31% in Las Vegas. High-skill metro areas most exposed — reversing prior automation patterns.

sources.title: How Adaptable Are American Workers to AI-Induced Job Displacement?
sources.excerpt: 6.1 million workers in AI-exposed roles lack adaptive capacity; 86% are women. Vulnerability concentrated in college towns and state capitals in Mountain West and Midwest.

sources.title: Uneven geographic and demographic patterns of AI adoption
sources.excerpt: AI usage heavily concentrated by income and geography globally; within US, workforce composition matters more than income for adoption patterns.

sources.title: Bridging Skill Gaps for the Future: New Jobs Creation in the AI Age
sources.excerpt: Employment 3.6% lower in AI-vulnerable occupations in regions with high AI-skill demand after 5 years; geographic divergence driven by skill concentration.
